Submit Search Query Open Search Input Popular Searches registrar academic calendar courses student accounts human resources library study abroad clarkyou bookstore campus map handshake Featured Sites Explore Areas of Study Visit Our International Center Open Search Bar Close Search Bar New Students Home New Students First Steps Once you pay your deposit, you are officially a new student at Clark. Next, set up your Clark account to receive official University Communications. Undergraduate Students: Pay Your Deposit Graduate Students: Pay Your Deposit Activate Your Clark Account Orientation Undergraduate Students Meet your adviser, sign up for classes, join clubs, and get ready to become a Clarkie. Graduate Students Get ready for Clark and attend the Orientation offered by your school or department. International Students If you are an international student, we invite you to campus before general Orientation starts. First-Year Experience for Undergraduate Students Clark’s First-Year Experience (FYE) begins in the summer and continues throughout the year. FYE includes academic advising, Orientation, Clark Navigator, the First-Year Intensive course, and living in first-year residence halls. Explore FYE Division of Student Success Your education doesn’t start and end in the classroom. Visit the Division of Student Success for more resources related to your life and learning at Clark. Submit Search Query Open Search Input Popular Searches registrar academic calendar courses student accounts human resources library study abroad clarkyou bookstore campus map handshake Featured Sites Explore Areas of Study Visit Our International Center Open Search Bar Close Search Bar For Parents and Families Home For Parents and Families Guide for Families Healthy Clark Welcome, parents and family members! We’re excited to have you in the Clark community. This is a special time for your entire family, and we want to help you stay involved and informed during your student’s time with us. Here, you’ll find useful links to keep you in the loop about life on campus, events, news and resources. Stay connected. Value and Affordability When it comes to paying for college, the roadmap is not the same for everyone. These links will help guide you and give you the necessary contacts so we can work together to make the process less daunting. Accelerated B.A./Master’s Program Financial Aid and Scholarships Rankings and Recognition Student Employment Tuition and Fees Campus Life Clark encourages parents and family members to participate in campus life, whether by attending events or keeping up with developments on our online news hubs. Of course, we always hope you can join us in person, but if not, we’re only a click away. Athletics Campus Living Center for Counseling and Personal Growth Commencement Diversity and Inclusion Division of Student Success Health and Wellness Health Services International Center New Student Orientation Wellness Education Academics Overview Curriculum First-Year Experience Careers, Internships, and Outcomes Browse the sites below to see the many career and internship resources available to your student. Career Connections Center ClarkCONNECT Funding for Opportunities Handshake Outcomes Student Employment Ways to connect Our social media profiles provide an easy way to stay connected to the Clark experience. Find the channel, or channels, that work best for you, and be sure to follow us. # Page 6: Alumni - Alumni | Clark University
Alumni | Clark University Skip to content Clark University Honor Roll Give Campaign Clark Alumni Toggle main menu Enter a search query. Submit Search Query Enter a search query. Submit Search Query Connect and Network Click to open menu. Clark Black Alumni Association (CBAA) Clark LGBTQ+ Alumni Association (CLAA) Alumni Around the World Volunteer Click to open menu. Upcoming Events Past Events Alumni Weekend Resources and Services Meet the Team Action Items Honor Roll Give Campaign Clark Connect and Network Clark Black Alumni Association (CBAA) Clark LGBTQ+ Alumni Association (CLAA) Alumni Around the World Volunteer Alumni Council GOLD Council Hall of Fame Committee Alumni Weekend – Reunion Volunteers Events Upcoming Events Past Events Alumni Weekend Resources and Services Meet the Team Welcome, Clark Alumni! Your connection with Clark begins as a student and lasts a lifetime. Strengthen your relationship with Clark and the global alumni community through special events, volunteer experiences, philanthropic opportunities, social media, and much more. Build Your Network Clark alumni are ready to reconnect, network, and build lifelong friendships. Explore the opportunities that exist within our alumni network, including professional development and networking opportunities and connecting with alumni in your area. Join ClarkCONNECT Network on Clark LinkedIn Connect with Classes on Facebook Give Back The Clark Fund Learn about different giving opportunities and how you can support Clark. ClarkCONNECT Connect with current students and fellow alumni through the ClarkCONNECT networking platform. Volunteer Share your time and expertise in one of many rewarding volunteer experiences. Resources and Services The benefits of a Clark experience don’t stop after graduation. There are many resources available to alumni both on campus and virtually — including help with career and educational development, access to on-campus services, and opportunities to share your life updates. View All Resources Campus Store Career Resources Kneller Fitness Center Library Services Transcripts Tuition Discounts News and Publications From the online ClarkNow news hub to the monthly e-newsletter and semiannual Clark magazine, there are plenty of ways for you to stay connected with what’s happening at Clark. # Page 7: 
		Visit	 - Visit - Undergraduate Admissions
Visit - Undergraduate Admissions Skip to content Clark University Undergraduate Admissions Toggle main menu Enter a search query. Submit Search Query Enter a search query. Submit Search Query Apply Click to open menu. First-Year Students Transfer Students International Students Visit Cost and Financial Aid Click to open menu. Cost of Attendance Merit-Based Aid Need-Based Aid Regional Incentive Grant Application Process Click to open menu. Why Apply Early Decision? Connect with Clark Click to open menu. Request Information Find Your Admissions Counselor Interviews Information for School Counselors Apply First-Year Students Transfer Students International Students Visit Cost and Financial Aid Cost of Attendance Merit-Based Aid Need-Based Aid Regional Incentive Grant Application Process Why Apply Early Decision? Connect with Clark Request Information Find Your Admissions Counselor Interviews Information for School Counselors Visit Undergraduate Admission Visit Finding your perfect school is all about fit — and the only way to know for sure if something fits you is by trying it on for yourself. Attending an information session and student-led tour is a fantastic way to get to know us. You’ll have the chance to connect with counselors and current students to learn more about the undergraduate experience. Want to explore even further? Sign up for special events, where you can take a specialty tour focused on your area of interest, sit in on a class, and more. No matter how you choose to visit Clark in person, we can’t wait to meet you. CAMPUS TOUR Get an up-close look at our campus, and visit the residence halls, dining halls, classrooms, and athletic center. Discover life at Clark. Register to visit Our campus and location About Worcester Find out more Meet your counselor Your admissions counselor can answer any of your questions. Admissions Counselors Schedule an interview Let’s chat. We recommend that you sign up for an interview to get to know us. Interviews Apply Are you a Clarkie? Start your application here. Apply Explore Clark virtually Virtual Information Session Check out our virtual information session where we take you through a Clark education. It’s equal parts liberal arts, research university, and hands-on learning. And it all takes place in the globally diverse city we love so much: Worcester. Interactive campus map Virtual information sessions and webinars Other ways to visit Group visits To schedule a group visit, please contact our office at least 30 days before your desired date. You can request a visit by emailing groupvisits@clarku.edu , and our group visit coordinators will process your request. For any questions, feel free to call us at 1-508-793-7431. We offer a variety of activities for your visit, including information sessions led by an admissions counselor, guided campus tours, and self-guided tour options. Our coordinators can assist in selecting the best activities for your group, and requests for additional options will be considered individually. Please provide the number of visitors you plan to bring, and ensure there is one chaperone for every 10 students. School counselor visits We love connecting with college counselors from high schools across the U.S. and around the world. We invite you to visit our campus, meet our admissions staff, and discover the exceptional educational experience Clark offers your students. If your schedule allows, we’d love to take you to the Cougar Café or The Den for a cup of coffee. To arrange your visit, register in our portal or email admissions@clarku.edu . Take the next step Experience what it’s like to study at a small research university with a strong liberal arts core. Visit Apply Not ready yet? Contact us to request more information . Contact Information Undergraduate Admissions Office Location 3 Maywood Street Worcester, MA 01610 1-508-793-7431 admissions@clarku.edu Office hours 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday – Friday Selected Saturdays in the Fall and Spring Apply Undergrad Apply Grad Give Contact Us Helpful Links Helpful Links Report a Concern Campus Safety Events Offices Employment Website Feedback Follow Us See more of us on Facebook See more of us on Twitter See more of us on Instagram See more of us on TikTok See more of us on YouTube See more of us on LinkedIn See more of us on Threads Return to Clark University Homepage Challenge Convention. # Page 9: ClarkYOU Login - Sign In
Sign In JavaScript required JavaScript is required. This web browser does not support JavaScript or JavaScript in this web browser is not enabled. To find out if your web browser supports JavaScript or to enable JavaScript, see web browser help. Sign in with your organizational account User Account Password Keep me signed in Sign in Please use your Clark University Email Address to sign in. Each student, faculty, and staff member must electronically affirm their agreement with The Clark Commitment. If you need additional assistance, contact the ITS Help Desk at helpdesk@clarku.edu or 508-793-7745. © 2018 Microsoft www.clarku.edu Help Desk

# Page 10: Courses and Schedules - Courses and Schedules | Registrar's Office | Clark University
Courses and Schedules | Registrar's Office | Clark University Skip to content Clark University Clark University Registrar’s Office Toggle main menu Enter a search query. Submit Search Query Enter a search query. Submit Search Query Courses and Schedules Academic Catalog Academic Calendars Transcripts Students Faculty/Advisor Courses and Schedules Academic Catalog Academic Calendars Transcripts Students Faculty/Advisor Courses and Schedules Home Courses and Schedules Clark University students web register through the CUWeb portal. Course offerings are published at the start of advising each semester. Select the semester below for course schedules, registration dates, and final exam periods. Additional information such as the Academic Calendar, Academic Catalog, and Web Registration Instructions are included within the Registrar’s Office website. Many classroom spaces are viewable online along with a list of their Software by navigating to the ITS webpage . Class Standing Current class level for undergraduate students is calculated by the number of units earned. 0-7.99 units completed = First Year class standing 8-15.99 units completed = Sophomore class standing 16-23.99 units completed = Junior class standing 24 or more units = Senior class standing Online registration priority dates for undergraduate students(Fall & Spring), however, are determined by the student’s anticipated class as of the next semester, which includes BOTH earned units and currently registered units. For example, if a student has 12 earned units (current sophomore class) and is registered for 4 units this semester (total of 16), then that student’s anticipated class for the next semester is junior. Thus, the student’s “class for registration purposes” is junior. Please refer to the Prepare for Registration tile in your web account to verify your class standing for registration purposes. NOTE: Undergraduate In-season NCAA athletes may be assigned to an earlier class for registration. Please contact the Athletics Department if you have any questions about your status &/or time block. Undergraduate students with approved registration accommodations may be assigned to the first day of registration, contact SAS if you have questions. Honors Experience Program students may also be able to register beginning the first day of registration, contact your Honors Advisor if you have questions. A student may be going into their third year however if they did not take 4 units each semester &/or withdrew/failed a course, then they would register with the Sophomores. Enrollment Status Enrollment statuses are used to determine financial aid eligibility, loan deferment, FICA exemption, health insurance, and so on. After each term begins, enrollment statuses are reported to the National Student Clearinghouse several times in the semester to ensure that loan agencies have accurate and up-to-date enrollment information for you, as is required by federal regulations. Registration enrollment statuses and criteria are defined as follows: Enrollment Status Unit Criteria Full-time 3.00 and up Three-quarter time 1.75 to 2.75 Half-time 1.50 Less than half-time 0.25-1.25 Questions pertaining to the above definitions as they relate to financial aid or loan deferment, please contact Financial Assistance . Questions related to health insurance or FICA exemption, please contact your Student Account Counselor . Web Registration Schedule and Course Grids Spring 2025 Advising begins Tuesday, Oct. 29, 2024. Course grids will be posted at noon. Submit Search Query Open Search Input Popular Searches registrar academic calendar courses student accounts human resources library study abroad clarkyou bookstore campus map handshake Featured Sites Explore Areas of Study Visit Our International Center Open Search Bar Close Search Bar Our Campus and Location Home Who We Are Our Campus and Location Campus Map, Virtual Tour, and Directions Visitor Parking Traveling to Clark Where to Stay in Worcester Worcester Transportation Scroll to Section Campus Map, Virtual Tour, and Directions Visitor Parking Traveling to Clark Where to Stay in Worcester Worcester Transportation Undergraduate Admissions Campus Visits Undergraduate Admissions Virtual Visits Graduate Admissions Visits Our location AT A GLANCE 72 Acres Total for Campus 30+ Restaurants Within 6 Blocks of Campus 8 Colleges and Universities in Worcester Clark University and Worcester: the Heart of New England Clark University’s 72-acre, tree-filled campus is located in Worcester, Massachusetts, known as “the Heart of New England.” Our location in the center of the state makes us easily accessible from just about any point in New England, including Boston (one hour), Providence (45 minutes), and Portland, Maine (two hours). We’re also an easy 3-1/2-hour drive from New York City. An Ideal Place to Build Connections Our students benefit from Worcester’s proximity to Boston, Providence, even New York — and the abundant opportunities for entertainment, internships, and careers within our home city and beyond. Learn More about Worcester Find Your Clark Destination Campus Map Navigate your way around Clark University with our campus map. Getting from A to B, or even Z, is easy. Interactive Virtual Tour Campus Map Google Directions All roads eventually lead to Clark University. Find your most direct route here with Google’s help. Get Directions Visitor Parking Visitors driving to Clark will find several convenient areas to park while on campus. Parking permits are available from both the Undergraduate and Graduate Admissions offices. All cars parked in Clark University Parking Areas (see Printable Campus Map) must display this permit. Some on-street parking is permitted, but please check street signs carefully for restrictions. Undergraduate Admissions Office Please pick up a permit at: The Admissions Center 1 Maywood Street Admissions visitor parking is available in the Maywood Street Parking Lot. If this is full, please try the Downing Street Parking Garage next to the Kneller Athletic Center; enter and exit on Downing Street only. Spaces may also be available in the outdoor lot on Woodland Street (behind #2 on the Campus Map). Graduate Admissions Office Please pick up a permit at: The Graduate Admissions Office 122 Woodland Street Worcester, MA 01610 Parking is available in the outdoor lots on Woodland Street or Charlotte Street, or on the top level of the parking garage (#39 on the Campus Map), enter and exit on Downing Street only. Additionally, there is significant on-street parking in the area. Other Offices on Campus If you are not an Admissions Office visitor, please contact the office or academic department you are planning to visit to find out where you should park and obtain a permit. Traveling to Clark ... By Air You have two main options for traveling via air: Boston Logan International Airport , then take a train or bus from Boston to Union Station, Worcester, and a taxi/ride-hailing service from there to Clark. Worcester Regional Airport : JetBlue, American, and Delta fly to several U.S. destinations. Take a taxi/ride-hailing service from the airport to Clark, about four miles. Other airports include Providence, R.I. , Manchester, N.H. , and Hartford, Conn. , but getting to Clark from these locations is often more complicated than from the Boston or Worcester airports. Getting to Clark from Boston: The cheap but indirect route Take a train or bus to Union Station in downtown Worcester, where you will need to take a taxi or ride-hailing service to get to Clark. Getting to Clark from Boston: The direct but slightly more costly route Use a shared van/limousine service like Knights Limousine Service , to pick you up at Boston airport and bring you directly to campus. Many students use this option. Be sure to make reservations early and allow for travel time. The trip from Boston to Worcester can take more than an hour at peak travel times. This option is cheaper if you travel with a group. By Train Worcester’s Union Station is approximately three miles from campus. It’s serviced by Amtrak’s Lake Shore Limited and Regional Lines, and the MBTA Commuter Rail from Boston. The best way to get to Clark from Union Station is by taxi or ride-hailing service (information below). For train schedules and fares contact: Amtrak 1-800-872-7245 MBTA Commuter Rail 1-800-392-6100 By Bus Worcester’s Union Station is serviced by Greyhound and Peter Pan. The best way to get to Clark from Union Station is by taxi (information below). For bus schedules and fares from Boston, New York and Washington, D.C. contact: Greyhound 1-800-229-9424 Peter Pan 1-800-343-9999 By Taxi A taxi or ride-hailing service can bring you to Clark from Union Station (Worcester’s bus and train station): Bullet Yellow Cab: 1-508-754-3211 Red Cab: 1-508-792-9999 Uber Lyft Where to Stay in Worcester Recommended Hotels Below are nearby hotels recommended for families traveling to Clark for Undergraduate Admissions visits: AC Hotel Courtyard by Marriott Worcester Hampton Inn & Suites Worcester Holiday Inn Express Worcester Downtown Hilton Garden Inn Worcester For additional questions about traveling to Clark, please email admissions@clarku.edu . Worcester Transportation How can you travel to Clark University? Worcester’s transportation options have you covered by road, rail, and air. Direct flights via JetBlue, American Airlines, and Delta connect you to U.S. and international cities. Trains Worcester Regional Transit Authority (WRTA) Buses Worcester Airport Train Station People and Places Our Campus, Our Community Clark University, Worcester, MA Clark University grad student Stanley Greidinger builds a snowman on the campus green. Submit Search Query You Can Get There from Here, and Back Again Clark University provides multiple modes of transportation for use by the campus community, ensuring students, faculty, and staff can safely travel throughout the campus, Worcester, and beyond. ClarkRIDE Clark RIDE is the University’s on-call safe-ride program that provides transportation for students, faculty, and staff. Within a 1.25mile radius of 950 Main street. Learn More Parking Lots and Permits Buy a parking permit and view parking lots throughout campus. Parking services are managed by University Police. Find out why Trending at Clark Indigenous heavy metal and whale song A new book by environmental geographer Max Ritts, explores the evolving sonic landscape of British Columbia’s North Coast and the Gitga’at First Nation community’s response to encroaching development and environmental change. Resonant ecology Does online influencing have a place in the business world? On this episode of Challenge. Change., Professors Lawrence Norman and Tim Hally ’19, MBA ’20 in Clark’s School of Business, weigh in on how LinkedInfluencers are shaping conversations about their industries. Listen to the podcast Congratulations Jeffrey Lurie ’73, owner of the Philadelphia Eagles Read about his journey from his time at Clark, where he learned to go after things that others would say were conventionally unrealistic, to the highest echelons of the NFL. Superbowl win Latest news Upcoming events Altogether different for the greater good Clark is built for the kind of unconventional and independent thinking that allows us to value the imperfect and navigate the unexpected. We move through the world with confidence and curiosity, eager to discover what awaits and emboldened to act when our moment arises. Explore their work 8:1 Student-to-faculty ratio In the classroom 65% First-year students receive need-based financial aid Affordability 100% Students complete an internship or experiential learning Hands-on 64 Majors, minors, and concentrations Majors and minors Discovery and Impact We think differently. We ask hard and good questions. We break down barriers to new knowledge and positive action. Cyanobacteria produce oxygen for life on earth. Why are viruses killing them? Funded by $1.1 million in NSF grants, researchers dive into an undersea war of the microbes. Understand the living world Sustainable cities How can migrants help cities become more sustainable? Geospatial analytics What can we do with 250,000 terabytes of satellite data? Creative arts Why do the operas of Puccini still resonate? Climate and Global Change Could traditional knowledge hold the answer to feeding the world? Political Science What can Euripides teach us about the role of grief and rage in contemporary society? Science and health What does it mean to be masculine? Admissions Clarkies are curious about the world and their place in it. We put our knowledge into action to make a difference. Photo by Natalie Hoang ’25 We are a force for change Clark University cultivates dynamic, hands-on educational experiences so together, we can connect extraordinary ideas and create far-reaching impact. At Clark, you’re welcomed from the moment you set foot on campus. Our community is diverse, creative, and intellectually daring, and enriched by the wide variety of backgrounds our students bring. Here, we challenge you to imagine a better world — and then create it. Our Mission We are united by our mission and it lies at the core of our work. President and leadership Learn more about our vision for Clark’s future and get the latest updates. Diversity and inclusion We live diversity and inclusion; inclusive excellence is our shared vision. Fast Facts At a glance 2,372 Undergraduate students 1,776 Graduate students 20 Average undergraduate class size 9:1 Student-to-faculty ratio 67 Undergraduate majors (including student-designed) Diversity and Inclusion 'We all connect here' A group of student leaders came together to create a space where they could find connection and share their perspectives. Read the story The Clark Story A lot has happened since 1887, when Jonas Gilman Clark founded Clark University as the first all-graduate school in the United States. Clark’s history is steeped in innovations that have shaped our lives. HISTORY AND TRADITIONS We Love Worcester New England’s second-largest city, Worcester, Massachusetts is a hub for biotech, higher education, health care, the arts, and is home to a thriving “pop-up” culture. Explore Worcester The Clark Approach We take an interdisciplinary and hands-on approach to solving contemporary problems. Knowledge in Action In the classroom and through research, we’re focused on putting knowledge into action and making a difference. Learn More Global Reach Members of the Clark community can be found across the globe, gaining a deeper understanding of our world. Learn More Environment and Sustainability We offer programs and courses that delve into green issues to explore the multi-layered impacts of climate change. Submit Search Query Open Search Input Popular Searches registrar academic calendar courses student accounts human resources library study abroad clarkyou bookstore campus map handshake Featured Sites Explore Areas of Study Visit Our International Center Open Search Bar Close Search Bar Fast Facts Home Who We Are Fast Facts clark At a GLANCE 486 First-Year Students 84% Percentage of Undergraduate Students Receiving Financial Aid $514 million Clark University Endowment Clark University was founded in 1887 as one of the first all-graduate institutions in the country. Today, Clark promotes a rigorous liberal arts curriculum within the context of a research experience that addresses challenges on a global scale. We’re privately funded, coeducational, and nonsectarian, and we offer bachelor’s, master’s, certificate, and doctoral degree programs in a wide range of disciplines. Our Faculty Libraries Academic Catalog Academic Calendar Courses and Schedules Academic Affairs Diversity and Inclusion Resources Quick Links ClarkYOU Login Courses and Schedules Academic Calendar Office Directory People Directory Campus Maps and Directions Clark Transportation Info For Students New Students Faculty & Staff Parents & Families Alumni Visit Give Enter a search query. Submit Search Query Open Search Input Popular Searches registrar academic calendar courses student accounts human resources library study abroad clarkyou bookstore campus map handshake Featured Sites Explore Areas of Study Visit Our International Center Open Search Bar Close Search Bar Our Mission Home Who We Are Our Mission See Also: President and Leadership History and Traditions Clark University’s mission is to educate undergraduate and graduate students to be imaginative and contributing citizens of the world, and to advance the frontiers of knowledge and understanding through rigorous scholarship and creative effort. The University seeks to prepare students to meet the challenges of a complex and rapidly changing society. In students and faculty, Clark fosters a commitment to excellence in studying traditional academic disciplines, as well as innovation in exploring questions that cross disciplinary boundaries. The free pursuit of inquiry and the free exchange of ideas are central to that commitment. The focus of Clark’s academic program is a liberal-arts education enriched by interactions among undergraduate students, graduate students, and faculty, and is closely linked to a select number of professional programs. Clark also serves students who wish to continue formal education throughout their lives. The intellectual and personal growth of students is enhanced by a wide variety of educational programs and extracurricular activities. Clark believes that intellectual growth must be accompanied by the development of values, the cultivation of responsible independence, and the appreciation of a range of perspectives. Clark’s academic community has long been distinguished by the pursuit of scientific inquiry and humanistic studies, enlivened by a concern for significant social issues. Among many other scholarly endeavors, Clark contributes to understanding human development, assessing relationships between people and the environment, and managing risk in a technological society. Clark is dedicated to being a dynamic community of learners able to thrive in today’s increasingly interrelated societies. The University maintains a national and international character, attracting high-caliber students and faculty from all quarters of the globe. As a university residing in an urban context, Clark also strives to address the needs and opportunities of contemporary urban life. Clark’s intimate academic setting and tradition of “elbow teaching” provide many opportunities for students to pursue knowledge through participation. High expectations, as well as easy access to the scholar-teacher faculty, encourage students to become autonomous learners. Clark’s international and interdisciplinary orientation is combined with a tradition of strong self-direction among students and faculty. These attributes enhance the University’s ability to contribute to the development of new modes of thought and to the advancement of society through the creation and transmission of knowledge. Submit Search Query Open Search Input Popular Searches registrar academic calendar courses student accounts human resources library study abroad clarkyou bookstore campus map handshake Featured Sites Explore Areas of Study Visit Our International Center Open Search Bar Close Search Bar History and Traditions Home Who We Are History and Traditions For more than 130 years, Clark University has thrived at the nexus of world-class teaching, boundary-pushing discovery, and creative invention. The father of rocket science. The founder of the American Psychological Association. A co-inventor of the birth control pill. Members of our community have always challenged convention and found ways to change our world for the better. Letting Loose Before Finals Spree Day An evolving event since 1903, Clarkies let loose when classes are canceled one day each spring. Then it was rope pulls and greased pole climbs; now, it’s bounce houses, bands, and burgers. View More Annual Events A Global Party International Gala Produced and performed by students, Clark’s popular annual spring showcase of international dance and music — from traditional to contemporary — celebrates the diverse cultures and talents of our community. View More Annual Events 10 Things You Don’t Know About Clark The launch pad of the space age Physics professor and Clark alumnus Robert Goddard conducted his pioneering rocketry research in Clark laboratories. In 1926, he launched a liquid-fueled rocket on his aunt’s farm in Auburn, earning him the moniker “Father of Modern Rocketry.” The first book on the moon When he stepped onto the moon in 1969, astronaut Buzz Aldrin carried with him two miniature autobiographies of Robert Goddard. He later gave a signed copy to Esther Goddard, the physicist’s widow, who donated the book to Clark’s library. Freud’s only lectures outside Europe Sigmund Freud presented his Clark lectures in 1909 as part of a series of conferences held in observance of the University’s 20th anniversary. It would be Freud’s only visit to America, and his only lectures outside of Europe. Paul Siple invented the wind chill In his doctoral research, Paul Siple, Ph.D. ’39, advanced the theory of wind chill and created an index to measure it — the wind chill factor. He later traveled seven times to Antarctica and named a mountain range there after Clark. Clark professor made Nobel Prize history In 1907, former Clark physics professor Albert Michelson became the first American awarded a Nobel Prize in the sciences for the development of the interferometer, an instrument designed to measure lengths and velocities of light. The birthplace of the Pill While a biology professor at Clark, Gregory Pincus conducted research paving the way for the birth control pill. He later founded the Worcester Foundation of Experimental Biology, which released the final version of the Pill to the public in 1960. TR addressed Clark’s first commencement President Theodore Roosevelt delivered the commencement address for Clark College’s first public undergraduate commencement ceremonies in 1905. Degrees were conferred on Clark’s class of 43 men. The ‘father of black psychology’ In 1920 African-American Francis Cecil Sumner earned a Ph.D. in psychology at Clark, becoming the first black person in the U.S. to earn a doctorate in that field. He would go on to found the department of psychology at Howard University. Commemorating a force of nature Heteropsyllus nunni , a minute crustacean inhabiting estuaries along the east coast of North America, was named for former biology professor Rudolph Nunnemacher. Both loved and feared by his students, he was one of Clark’s longest-serving professors. Rocking the stage at Clark Jimi Hendrix, The Grateful Dead, Janis Joplin, Bruce Springsteen and James Taylor all performed at Clark. The Grateful Dead blew out the sound system. (It’s been fixed.) The launch pad of the space age Physics professor and Clark alumnus Robert Goddard conducted his pioneering rocketry research in Clark laboratories. In 1926, he launched a liquid-fueled rocket on his aunt’s farm in Auburn, earning him the moniker “Father of Modern Rocketry.” 1 /10 Milestones 1887 A new university Massachusetts passes legislation incorporating Clark University. Two years later, under the presidency of G. Stanley Hall, the university opens its doors in Worcester, Massachusetts as the first graduate-study-only institution in the United States, with degrees offered in biology, chemistry, mathematics, physics, and psychology. Under Hall, its program in psychology becomes nationally competitive, a position it still holds. The university’s initial emphasis on groundbreaking research continues today through its academic departments, as well as the George Perkins Marsh Institute, Clark Labs, Strassler Center for Holocaust and Genocide Studies, Mosakowski Institute for Public Enterprise, and the Hiatt Center for Urban Education. ··· 1887 A new university Massachusetts passes legislation incorporating Clark University. Two years later, under the presidency of G. Stanley Hall, the university opens its doors in Worcester, Massachusetts as the first graduate-study-only institution in the United States, with degrees offered in biology, chemistry, mathematics, physics, and psychology. Under Hall, its program in psychology becomes nationally competitive, a position it still holds. The university’s initial emphasis on groundbreaking research continues today through its academic departments, as well as the George Perkins Marsh Institute, Clark Labs, Strassler Center for Holocaust and Genocide Studies, Mosakowski Institute for Public Enterprise, and the Hiatt Center for Urban Education. ··· Close Modal 1887 A new university Massachusetts passes legislation incorporating Clark University. Two years later, under the presidency of G. Stanley Hall, the university opens its doors in Worcester, Massachusetts as the first graduate-study-only institution in the United States, with degrees offered in biology, chemistry, mathematics, physics, and psychology. Under Hall, its program in psychology becomes nationally competitive, a position it still holds. The university’s initial emphasis on groundbreaking research continues today through its academic departments, as well as the George Perkins Marsh Institute, Clark Labs, Strassler Center for Holocaust and Genocide Studies, Mosakowski Institute for Public Enterprise, and the Hiatt Center for Urban Education. 1902 An undergraduate college Two years after Jonas Clark’s death, Clark College, a liberal arts college for men, is established under the presidency of Carroll D. Wright, the first U.S. Commissioner of Labor. In his will, Clark stated that “it is my earnest desire … that the said University … be wholly free from every kind of denominational or sectarian control, bias or limitation, and that its doors may be ever open to all classes and persons whatsoever may be their religious faith or political sympathies, or to whatever creed, sect or party they may belong.” Today Clark prides itself on its commitment to inclusive excellence, and requires all undergraduates to complete an inclusive excellence requirement. ··· 1902 An undergraduate college Two years after Jonas Clark’s death, Clark College, a liberal arts college for men, is established under the presidency of Carroll D. Wright, the first U.S. Commissioner of Labor. In his will, Clark stated that “it is my earnest desire … that the said University … be wholly free from every kind of denominational or sectarian control, bias or limitation, and that its doors may be ever open to all classes and persons whatsoever may be their religious faith or political sympathies, or to whatever creed, sect or party they may belong.” Today Clark prides itself on its commitment to inclusive excellence, and requires all undergraduates to complete an inclusive excellence requirement. ··· Close Modal 1902 An undergraduate college Two years after Jonas Clark’s death, Clark College, a liberal arts college for men, is established under the presidency of Carroll D. Wright, the first U.S. Commissioner of Labor. In his will, Clark stated that “it is my earnest desire … that the said University … be wholly free from every kind of denominational or sectarian control, bias or limitation, and that its doors may be ever open to all classes and persons whatsoever may be their religious faith or political sympathies, or to whatever creed, sect or party they may belong.” Today Clark prides itself on its commitment to inclusive excellence, and requires all undergraduates to complete an inclusive excellence requirement. 1920 One Clark With the resignations of G. Stanley Hall and Wright’s successor, Edmund Sanford, the presidencies of the college and university are combined under geographer and former Harvard University professor Wallace W. Atwood. The following year Atwood establishes what would become Clark’s world-renowned Graduate School of Geography, which has graduated more Ph.D.s in that field than any other in the United States. ··· 1920 One Clark With the resignations of G. Stanley Hall and Wright’s successor, Edmund Sanford, the presidencies of the college and university are combined under geographer and former Harvard University professor Wallace W. Atwood. The following year Atwood establishes what would become Clark’s world-renowned Graduate School of Geography, which has graduated more Ph.D.s in that field than any other in the United States. ··· Close Modal 1920 One Clark With the resignations of G. Stanley Hall and Wright’s successor, Edmund Sanford, the presidencies of the college and university are combined under geographer and former Harvard University professor Wallace W. Atwood. The following year Atwood establishes what would become Clark’s world-renowned Graduate School of Geography, which has graduated more Ph.D.s in that field than any other in the United States. 1942 Clark College goes co-ed While women had been earning graduate degrees at Clark (the first master’s and doctoral degrees awarded to women were granted in 1907 and 1908, respectively), the undergraduate college was restricted to men. That changes in 1942 with the admission of 73 women who shared classes with the 269 male undergraduates enrolled that year. Gradually, women were integrated into the administration and faculty. Alice Coonley Higgins became chair of the Board of Trustees in 1967, the first woman to assume this role at a private research university in the United States. By 1980, courses in women’s studies had coalesced into a formal concentration, and in 1992 Clark became the first university in the United States to offer a Ph.D. in women’s studies. The university now offers a B.A. degree in women’s and gender studies . ··· 1942 Clark College goes co-ed While women had been earning graduate degrees at Clark (the first master’s and doctoral degrees awarded to women were granted in 1907 and 1908, respectively), the undergraduate college was restricted to men. That changes in 1942 with the admission of 73 women who shared classes with the 269 male undergraduates enrolled that year. Gradually, women were integrated into the administration and faculty. Alice Coonley Higgins became chair of the Board of Trustees in 1967, the first woman to assume this role at a private research university in the United States. By 1980, courses in women’s studies had coalesced into a formal concentration, and in 1992 Clark became the first university in the United States to offer a Ph.D. in women’s studies. The university now offers a B.A. degree in women’s and gender studies . ··· Close Modal 1942 Clark College goes co-ed While women had been earning graduate degrees at Clark (the first master’s and doctoral degrees awarded to women were granted in 1907 and 1908, respectively), the undergraduate college was restricted to men. That changes in 1942 with the admission of 73 women who shared classes with the 269 male undergraduates enrolled that year. Gradually, women were integrated into the administration and faculty. Alice Coonley Higgins became chair of the Board of Trustees in 1967, the first woman to assume this role at a private research university in the United States. By 1980, courses in women’s studies had coalesced into a formal concentration, and in 1992 Clark became the first university in the United States to offer a Ph.D. in women’s studies. The university now offers a B.A. degree in women’s and gender studies . 1953 A commitment to adult education Clark’s Evening College initially offers bachelor of science degrees in General Studies and Business Administration, followed later by master’s degrees. Reestablished as today’s School of Professional Studies (SPS) with its focus on graduate education, SPS offers master’s degrees and certificates in areas ranging from information technology to public administration and supports campuses in Poland and China . ··· 1953 A commitment to adult education Clark’s Evening College initially offers bachelor of science degrees in General Studies and Business Administration, followed later by master’s degrees. Reestablished as today’s School of Professional Studies (SPS) with its focus on graduate education, SPS offers master’s degrees and certificates in areas ranging from information technology to public administration and supports campuses in Poland and China . ··· Close Modal 1953 A commitment to adult education Clark’s Evening College initially offers bachelor of science degrees in General Studies and Business Administration, followed later by master’s degrees. Reestablished as today’s School of Professional Studies (SPS) with its focus on graduate education, SPS offers master’s degrees and certificates in areas ranging from information technology to public administration and supports campuses in Poland and China . 1982 In the business of business Founded in 1982, Clark’s AACSB-accredited School of Management, which today attracts students from around the world, provides business education with an emphasis on ethical conduct, sustainability, and corporate social responsibility. In addition to supporting the undergraduate major in management, SOM offers graduate certificate and master’s degree programs. ··· 1982 In the business of business Founded in 1982, Clark’s AACSB-accredited School of Management, which today attracts students from around the world, provides business education with an emphasis on ethical conduct, sustainability, and corporate social responsibility. In addition to supporting the undergraduate major in management, SOM offers graduate certificate and master’s degree programs. ··· Close Modal 1982 In the business of business Founded in 1982, Clark’s AACSB-accredited School of Management, which today attracts students from around the world, provides business education with an emphasis on ethical conduct, sustainability, and corporate social responsibility. In addition to supporting the undergraduate major in management, SOM offers graduate certificate and master’s degree programs. 2000 A commitment to communities near and far The Department of International Development, Community, and Environment (IDCE) is established to foster environmental sustainability, social justice, and economic well-being in both the developing and developed worlds. By thinking critically, acting collaboratively, and engaging responsibly with challenges around the globe, IDCE faculty and students continue to build a more just, healthy, and sustainable world during their time at Clark and beyond. In addition to supporting an undergraduate major and minor, the department offers master’s degree programs. ··· 2000 A commitment to communities near and far The Department of International Development, Community, and Environment (IDCE) is established to foster environmental sustainability, social justice, and economic well-being in both the developing and developed worlds. By thinking critically, acting collaboratively, and engaging responsibly with challenges around the globe, IDCE faculty and students continue to build a more just, healthy, and sustainable world during their time at Clark and beyond. In addition to supporting an undergraduate major and minor, the department offers master’s degree programs. ··· Close Modal 2000 A commitment to communities near and far The Department of International Development, Community, and Environment (IDCE) is established to foster environmental sustainability, social justice, and economic well-being in both the developing and developed worlds. By thinking critically, acting collaboratively, and engaging responsibly with challenges around the globe, IDCE faculty and students continue to build a more just, healthy, and sustainable world during their time at Clark and beyond. In addition to supporting an undergraduate major and minor, the department offers master’s degree programs. 2009 A pioneering model for undergraduate education Clark convenes a first-of-its-kind National Conference on Liberal Education and Effective Practice, co-sponsored by the Mosakowski Institute for Public Enterprise and the Association of American Colleges and Universities. Three years later, Clark launches LEEP, its model for undergraduate education that combines a traditional liberal arts experience with authentic engagement in the world and workplace. ··· 2009 A pioneering model for undergraduate education Clark convenes a first-of-its-kind National Conference on Liberal Education and Effective Practice, co-sponsored by the Mosakowski Institute for Public Enterprise and the Association of American Colleges and Universities. Three years later, Clark launches LEEP, its model for undergraduate education that combines a traditional liberal arts experience with authentic engagement in the world and workplace. ··· Close Modal 2009 A pioneering model for undergraduate education Clark convenes a first-of-its-kind National Conference on Liberal Education and Effective Practice, co-sponsored by the Mosakowski Institute for Public Enterprise and the Association of American Colleges and Universities. Three years later, Clark launches LEEP, its model for undergraduate education that combines a traditional liberal arts experience with authentic engagement in the world and workplace. Founder Jonas G. Clark Successful Massachusetts entrepreneur, abolitionist, and book and art collector, Clark envisioned that his university would open with a rigorous but affordable undergraduate college for young men. Clark Presidents 1888–1920 G. Stanley Hall A pioneering psychologist, Hall founded the American Psychological Association and brought Sigmund Freud to campus for his only lectures in the United States. 1888–1920 G. Stanley Hall A pioneering psychologist, Hall founded the American Psychological Association and brought Sigmund Freud to campus for his only lectures in the United States. Close Modal 1888–1920 G. Atwood In addition to his tenure as president, Atwood served as director of the Graduate School of Geography, moving GSG to international prominence. 1920–1946 Wallace W. Jefferson Jefferson left a legacy of humane learning, a university strengthened in numbers and quality, and facilities that gave new dimensions to the Clark experience. 1946–1967 Howard B. Jackson Serving at a restless time in the nation’s history, Jackson oversaw completion of Goddard Library and launch of the Worcester Consortium for Higher Education. 1967–1970 Frederick H. Ferguson Ferguson, a well-traveled diplomat, created the Office of Academic Innovation to develop new courses and nontraditional modes of teaching. 1970-1973 Glenn W. Ferguson Ferguson, a well-traveled diplomat, created the Office of Academic Innovation to develop new courses and nontraditional modes of teaching. Close Modal 1970-1973 Glenn W. Ferguson Ferguson, a well-traveled diplomat, created the Office of Academic Innovation to develop new courses and nontraditional modes of teaching. 1974–1984 Mortimer H. Appley Appley, an accomplished academician, adeptly guided Clark through a period of fiscal uncertainty and established the Graduate School of Management. 1974–1984 Mortimer H. Appley Appley, an accomplished academician, adeptly guided Clark through a period of fiscal uncertainty and established the Graduate School of Management. Close Modal 1974–1984 Mortimer H. Traina A transformative leader, Traina envisioned, initiated, and championed the groundbreaking University Park Partnership, a national model for community engagement. 1984–2000 Richard P. Traina A transformative leader, Traina envisioned, initiated, and championed the groundbreaking University Park Partnership, a national model for community engagement. Bassett With key donors, Bassett fostered the creation of the Mosakowski Institute for Public Enterprise and the Adam Institute for Urban Teaching and School Practice. 2000–2010 John E. Angel Under Angel’s leadership, Clark launched its Liberal Education and Effective Practice (LEEP) curriculum, linking classroom and experiential learning. 2010–2020 David P. Angel Under Angel’s leadership, Clark launched its Liberal Education and Effective Practice (LEEP) curriculum, linking classroom and experiential learning. 2020–present David Fithian ’87 Fithian is applying his impressive professional experience and personal vision to the mission of shaping the next stage of Clark University, his alma mater. 2020–present David Fithian ’87 Fithian is applying his impressive professional experience and personal vision to the mission of shaping the next stage of Clark University, his alma mater. Submit Search Query Open Search Input Popular Searches registrar academic calendar courses student accounts human resources library study abroad clarkyou bookstore campus map handshake Featured Sites Explore Areas of Study Visit Our International Center Open Search Bar Close Search Bar President and Leadership Home Who We Are President and Leadership Office of the President Leadership Team Board of Trustees Since its founding in 1887, Clark University has benefited from leaders whose vision and resolve have created a learning institution of global consequence. Through the leadership of President David Fithian ’87, the counsel of the Board of Trustees, and the commitment and innovation of the provost, deans, and vice presidents, Clark has established itself as an institution unafraid to press against the boundaries of traditional thinking. Our leaders know the decisions they make on behalf of the University will have a ripple effect in all areas where Clark makes an impact — from Worcester to points across the world. Office of the President President David Fithian ’87 leads Clark University’s mission to provide an education that inspires our students to become transformative forces in their careers, communities, and the world, while fostering a campus culture that welcomes difference and drives accomplishment. Learn More University Leadership Under the direction of the president, the Clark University leadership team sustains and promotes the academic excellence and fiduciary health of the institution, carrying out the policies set by the Board of Trustees. Learn More Board of Trustees Clark’s trustees draw on their expertise in the fields of business, law, and higher education to shape the policies that guide the University’s growth, enhance its reputation, and ensure its standing as a destination of choice for academically engaged students. Submit Search Query Open Search Input Popular Searches registrar academic calendar courses student accounts human resources library study abroad clarkyou bookstore campus map handshake Featured Sites Explore Areas of Study Visit Our International Center Open Search Bar Close Search Bar Diversity and Inclusion Home Who We Are Diversity and Inclusion Progress Updates Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Initiatives Our Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Action Plan aims to move us ever closer toward a fully inclusive, just, and equitable Clark. Learn More Student Groups Students can choose from a variety of campus community organizations focused on social, cultural, and ethnic interests and identities. Several community groups are based out of the Office of Identity, Student Engagement, and Access (ISEA). Learn More about Community Groups At Clark, we work every day to build an inclusive learning environment that links with our academic mission to build new knowledge and seek truth everywhere. Our university is dynamic, multicultural, and always striving to be better. We believe each student deserves a learning experience that merges the distinctiveness of the individual with the power of community. Your perspectives, your talents, your history, and your voice are critical toward sustaining a campus that celebrates difference and fosters respect for all. Academics Center for Gender, Race, and Area Studies (CGRAS) The Center for Gender, Race, and Area Studies is an academic hub comprising interdisciplinary programs, from Africana Studies to Women’s and Gender Studies. Diversity and Inclusion Courses As part of its liberal arts curriculum, Clark requires all students to fulfill a Diversity and Inclusion course requirement. # Page 24: Our Campus and Location - Our Campus and Location | Clark University
Our Campus and Location | Clark University Skip to content Students New Students Faculty & Staff Parents & Families Alumni Visit Give Quick Links ClarkYOU Login Courses and Schedules Academic Calendar Office Directory People Directory Campus Maps and Directions Clark Transportation Go to ClarkU homepage. Submit Search Query Open Search Input Popular Searches registrar academic calendar courses student accounts human resources library study abroad clarkyou bookstore campus map handshake Featured Sites Explore Areas of Study Visit Our International Center Open Search Bar Close Search Bar Our Campus and Location Home Who We Are Our Campus and Location Campus Map, Virtual Tour, and Directions Visitor Parking Traveling to Clark Where to Stay in Worcester Worcester Transportation Scroll to Section Campus Map, Virtual Tour, and Directions Visitor Parking Traveling to Clark Where to Stay in Worcester Worcester Transportation Undergraduate Admissions Campus Visits Undergraduate Admissions Virtual Visits Graduate Admissions Visits Our location AT A GLANCE 72 Acres Total for Campus 30+ Restaurants Within 6 Blocks of Campus 8 Colleges and Universities in Worcester Clark University and Worcester: the Heart of New England Clark University’s 72-acre, tree-filled campus is located in Worcester, Massachusetts, known as “the Heart of New England.” Our location in the center of the state makes us easily accessible from just about any point in New England, including Boston (one hour), Providence (45 minutes), and Portland, Maine (two hours). We’re also an easy 3-1/2-hour drive from New York City. An Ideal Place to Build Connections Our students benefit from Worcester’s proximity to Boston, Providence, even New York — and the abundant opportunities for entertainment, internships, and careers within our home city and beyond. Learn More about Worcester Find Your Clark Destination Campus Map Navigate your way around Clark University with our campus map. Getting from A to B, or even Z, is easy. Interactive Virtual Tour Campus Map Google Directions All roads eventually lead to Clark University. Find your most direct route here with Google’s help. Get Directions Visitor Parking Visitors driving to Clark will find several convenient areas to park while on campus. Parking permits are available from both the Undergraduate and Graduate Admissions offices. All cars parked in Clark University Parking Areas (see Printable Campus Map) must display this permit. Some on-street parking is permitted, but please check street signs carefully for restrictions. Undergraduate Admissions Office Please pick up a permit at: The Admissions Center 1 Maywood Street Admissions visitor parking is available in the Maywood Street Parking Lot. If this is full, please try the Downing Street Parking Garage next to the Kneller Athletic Center; enter and exit on Downing Street only. Spaces may also be available in the outdoor lot on Woodland Street (behind #2 on the Campus Map). Graduate Admissions Office Please pick up a permit at: The Graduate Admissions Office 122 Woodland Street Worcester, MA 01610 Parking is available in the outdoor lots on Woodland Street or Charlotte Street, or on the top level of the parking garage (#39 on the Campus Map), enter and exit on Downing Street only. Additionally, there is significant on-street parking in the area. Other Offices on Campus If you are not an Admissions Office visitor, please contact the office or academic department you are planning to visit to find out where you should park and obtain a permit. Traveling to Clark ... By Air You have two main options for traveling via air: Boston Logan International Airport , then take a train or bus from Boston to Union Station, Worcester, and a taxi/ride-hailing service from there to Clark. Worcester Regional Airport : JetBlue, American, and Delta fly to several U.S. destinations. Take a taxi/ride-hailing service from the airport to Clark, about four miles. Other airports include Providence, R.I. , Manchester, N.H. , and Hartford, Conn. , but getting to Clark from these locations is often more complicated than from the Boston or Worcester airports. Getting to Clark from Boston: The cheap but indirect route Take a train or bus to Union Station in downtown Worcester, where you will need to take a taxi or ride-hailing service to get to Clark. Getting to Clark from Boston: The direct but slightly more costly route Use a shared van/limousine service like Knights Limousine Service , to pick you up at Boston airport and bring you directly to campus. Many students use this option. Be sure to make reservations early and allow for travel time. The trip from Boston to Worcester can take more than an hour at peak travel times. This option is cheaper if you travel with a group. By Train Worcester’s Union Station is approximately three miles from campus. It’s serviced by Amtrak’s Lake Shore Limited and Regional Lines, and the MBTA Commuter Rail from Boston. The best way to get to Clark from Union Station is by taxi or ride-hailing service (information below). For train schedules and fares contact: Amtrak 1-800-872-7245 MBTA Commuter Rail 1-800-392-6100 By Bus Worcester’s Union Station is serviced by Greyhound and Peter Pan. The best way to get to Clark from Union Station is by taxi (information below). For bus schedules and fares from Boston, New York and Washington, D.C. contact: Greyhound 1-800-229-9424 Peter Pan 1-800-343-9999 By Taxi A taxi or ride-hailing service can bring you to Clark from Union Station (Worcester’s bus and train station): Bullet Yellow Cab: 1-508-754-3211 Red Cab: 1-508-792-9999 Uber Lyft Where to Stay in Worcester Recommended Hotels Below are nearby hotels recommended for families traveling to Clark for Undergraduate Admissions visits: AC Hotel Courtyard by Marriott Worcester Hampton Inn & Suites Worcester Holiday Inn Express Worcester Downtown Hilton Garden Inn Worcester For additional questions about traveling to Clark, please email admissions@clarku.edu . Worcester Transportation How can you travel to Clark University? Worcester’s transportation options have you covered by road, rail, and air. Direct flights via JetBlue, American Airlines, and Delta connect you to U.S. and international cities. Trains Worcester Regional Transit Authority (WRTA) Buses Worcester Airport Train Station People and Places Our Campus, Our Community Clark University, Worcester, MA Clark University grad student Stanley Greidinger builds a snowman on the campus green. Submit Search Query Open Search Input Popular Searches registrar academic calendar courses student accounts human resources library study abroad clarkyou bookstore campus map handshake Featured Sites Explore Areas of Study Visit Our International Center Open Search Bar Close Search Bar Worcester Home Who We Are Our Campus and Location Worcester Worcester at a Glance 1731 Worcester Founded 55 City Parks 1 Minor League Baseball Team (Go, WooSox!) 106 Curated Murals 185,877 People Why We Love Worcester Worcester is a midsize city with big-city rhythms and spirit. This is a place of energy, opportunity, and attitude that you’ll want to explore, then make your own. Fueled by a $500 million downtown development project and its bustling Canal District, Worcester is experiencing an economic and physical transformation. New retail, restaurants, and residential spaces have invigorated the city and its residents. Where we live Our Neighborhood Clark is proud to be located in Worcester’s Main South neighborhood, a richly diverse and tightly knit community that has reimagined itself thanks to a dynamic partnership between the University and the city. Our students are not just visitors to Main South — they are participants, contributors, and good neighbors. Walk This Way Broad Meadow Brook The Broad Meadow Brook Conservation Center and Wildlife Sanctuary is a 400-acre oasis located within the city, though you’ll swear you’re hiking in the country. Green Day St. Patrick Day’s Parade Worcester takes a back seat to no city — not even Boston — when it comes to celebrating all things green. On parade day, everybody’s Irish. Show Your Moves Skating on the Oval Lace ’em up to enjoy one of Worcester’s newer traditions and one of its most fun. The oval on Worcester Common is open for ice skating throughout the winter. Let Your Geek Flag Fly That’s Entertainment Comic books, graphic novels, table-top gaming, and more pack this Worcester mainstay located at the corner of Park Avenue and — wait for it — Lois Lane. Time to thrash The Palladium Hair, harmony, and hell-raising set The Palladium apart from other city music venues, in decibel levels alone. The metal-rock gods haunt this raucous hall. The metal-rock gods haunt this raucous hall. The place to be Canal District This booming area has evolved into one of the city’s hippest hangouts, a place to hear great music, enjoy ethnic food, and experience the good times Worcester has to offer. A stone’s throw from Clark, the Canal District is a treat to visit during daylight hours, but the fun really starts after dark. Learn More On the menu Shrewsbury Street Everybody’s gotta eat, and Shrewsbury Street is where you’ll find exactly what you’re craving. Worcester’s “Restaurant Row” boasts more than 40 establishments whose offerings range from fine-dining to ethnic cuisine to diner meat loaf, all within 1.5 delicious miles. Bring your appetite. Learn More Play How do you pronounce "Worcester"? How Do You Pronounce ‘Worcester’? Named for a city in England, Worcester was incorporated in 1722. People have been mispronouncing it ever since. Learn how people pronounce “Worcester” nowadays. Students, faculty, and staff demonstrate. From Buzz to the Beatles 10 Very Worcester Things Roses are red … Home of the valentine The first American valentines were popularized and mass-produced by a Worcester woman named Esther Howland. Hearts have been gladdened (and broken) ever since. ··· Roses are red … Home of the valentine The first American valentines were popularized and mass-produced by a Worcester woman named Esther Howland. Don’t worry, be happy Creation of the Smiley Face In 1963, Worcester commercial artist Harvey Ball was commissioned to design an image that would boost morale among employees at a local insurance company. That image became the internationally known Smiley Face. ··· Don’t worry, be happy Creation of the Smiley Face In 1963, Worcester commercial artist Harvey Ball was commissioned to design an image that would boost morale among employees at a local insurance company. Buzz by the books An astronaut at Clark On May 19, 1969, astronaut Buzz Aldrin cut the ribbon on the newly built Goddard Library at Clark University. Two months later, he and Neil Armstrong were walking on the moon. ··· Buzz by the books An astronaut at Clark On May 19, 1969, astronaut Buzz Aldrin cut the ribbon on the newly built Goddard Library at Clark University. Pitching history Baseball’s first perfect game Lee Richmond of the Worcesters pitched the first perfect game in major league baseball history on June 12, 1880, in Worcester. A monument commemorates Richmond’s feat. ··· Pitching history Baseball’s first perfect game Lee Richmond of the Worcesters pitched the first perfect game in major league baseball history on June 12, 1880, in Worcester. A monument commemorates Richmond’s feat. ··· Close Modal Pitching history Baseball’s first perfect game Lee Richmond of the Worcesters pitched the first perfect game in major league baseball history on June 12, 1880, in Worcester. A monument commemorates Richmond’s feat. Worcester’s hit maker Introducing the Beatles The Beatles were four anonymous musicians from Liverpool until Dick “The Derby” Smith became the first DJ in the U.S. to play their first record, “She Loves You,” on radio station WORC. It caught on. ··· Worcester’s hit maker Introducing the Beatles The Beatles were four anonymous musicians from Liverpool until Dick “The Derby” Smith became the first DJ in the U.S. to play their first record, “She Loves You,” on radio station WORC. It caught on. ··· Close Modal Worcester’s hit maker Introducing the Beatles The Beatles were four anonymous musicians from Liverpool until Dick “The Derby” Smith became the first DJ in the U.S. to play their first record, “She Loves You,” on radio station WORC. It caught on. The Spy gets a scoop Declaration of Independence has its first reading On July 14, 1776, Isaiah Thomas, publisher of the Worcester-based Massachusetts Spy , gave the first public reading of the Declaration of Independence. He also made sure the Spy was the first paper to publish the historic document. ··· The Spy gets a scoop Declaration of Independence has its first reading On July 14, 1776, Isaiah Thomas, publisher of the Worcester-based Massachusetts Spy , gave the first public reading of the Declaration of Independence. He also made sure the Spy was the first paper to publish the historic document. ··· Close Modal The Spy gets a scoop Declaration of Independence has its first reading On July 14, 1776, Isaiah Thomas, publisher of the Worcester-based Massachusetts Spy , gave the first public reading of the Declaration of Independence. Novel appearances Twain and Dickens spoke here Worcester’s Mechanics Hall has hosted countless world-class musicians and comedic performers, but two of its most renowned presenters were the authors Mark Twain and Charles Dickens. ··· Novel appearances Twain and Dickens spoke here Worcester’s Mechanics Hall has hosted countless world-class musicians and comedic performers, but two of its most renowned presenters were the authors Mark Twain and Charles Dickens. ··· Close Modal Novel appearances Twain and Dickens spoke here Worcester’s Mechanics Hall has hosted countless world-class musicians and comedic performers, but two of its most renowned presenters were the authors Mark Twain and Charles Dickens. The sexual revolution launches Invention of the Pill The Worcester Foundation for Experimental Biology developed the first oral contraceptive during the 1950s and marketed it in 1960. The invention changed the social and political landscape for generations to come. ··· The sexual revolution launches Invention of the Pill The Worcester Foundation for Experimental Biology developed the first oral contraceptive during the 1950s and marketed it in 1960. The invention changed the social and political landscape for generations to come. ··· Close Modal The sexual revolution launches Invention of the Pill The Worcester Foundation for Experimental Biology developed the first oral contraceptive during the 1950s and marketed it in 1960. The invention changed the social and political landscape for generations to come. A Major legacy The Worcester Whirlwind makes history At the turn of the last century, Marshall “Major” Taylor, aka “The Worcester Whirlwind,” was the fastest bicyclist in the world. He was also among the first African-American athletes to confront racism in professional sports. ··· A Major legacy The Worcester Whirlwind makes history At the turn of the last century, Marshall “Major” Taylor, aka “The Worcester Whirlwind,” was the fastest bicyclist in the world. He was also among the first African-American athletes to confront racism in professional sports. ··· Close Modal A Major legacy The Worcester Whirlwind makes history At the turn of the last century, Marshall “Major” Taylor, aka “The Worcester Whirlwind,” was the fastest bicyclist in the world. He was also among the first African-American athletes to confront racism in professional sports. Submit Search Query Open Search Input Popular Searches registrar academic calendar courses student accounts human resources library study abroad clarkyou bookstore campus map handshake Featured Sites Explore Areas of Study Visit Our International Center Open Search Bar Close Search Bar Annual Events Home Who We Are History and Traditions Annual Events When We All Come Together Since 1903, Clark students have been gathering for Spree Day, letting loose before finals. If you see a bunch of students on the green dancing, eating, and playing on inflatable slides, you know it’s that time of year. The campus also turns out for Midnight Mayhem basketball in the fall, International Gala in the spring, and plenty of student, academic, and research events in between. To cap it all off: Commencement and Reunion in May. October Family and Friends Weekend Fall is a great time to enjoy New England. Families and friends visit with students, enjoy activities and special events, and connect with other Clarkies. October and April ClarkFEST Clark undergraduates present their research and creative work twice a year, at ClarkFEST in October and April. March/April International Gala The International Student Association organizes International Gala every year, with students from all over campus contributing their song and dance talents. April Spree Day Started in 1903, Spree Day — when classes are canceled and students enjoy a fun-filled day right before finals — is one of the most beloved traditions at Clark. April Graduate Student Multidisciplinary Conference This conference highlights the important scholarship produced by Clark’s talented graduate student community. May Commencement Undergraduate and graduate students step to the podium to receive their diplomas, and celebrate their achievements with family and friends. May Reunion Each year during Commencement weekend, Clark alumni arrive on campus to reconnect with old friends, meet the newest alumni, and dance under the stars. Submit Search Query Open Search Input Popular Searches registrar academic calendar courses student accounts human resources library study abroad clarkyou bookstore campus map handshake Featured Sites Explore Areas of Study Visit Our International Center Open Search Bar Close Search Bar Our Campus and Location Home Who We Are Our Campus and Location Campus Map, Virtual Tour, and Directions Visitor Parking Traveling to Clark Where to Stay in Worcester Worcester Transportation Scroll to Section Campus Map, Virtual Tour, and Directions Visitor Parking Traveling to Clark Where to Stay in Worcester Worcester Transportation Undergraduate Admissions Campus Visits Undergraduate Admissions Virtual Visits Graduate Admissions Visits Our location AT A GLANCE 72 Acres Total for Campus 30+ Restaurants Within 6 Blocks of Campus 8 Colleges and Universities in Worcester Clark University and Worcester: the Heart of New England Clark University’s 72-acre, tree-filled campus is located in Worcester, Massachusetts, known as “the Heart of New England.” Our location in the center of the state makes us easily accessible from just about any point in New England, including Boston (one hour), Providence (45 minutes), and Portland, Maine (two hours). We’re also an easy 3-1/2-hour drive from New York City. An Ideal Place to Build Connections Our students benefit from Worcester’s proximity to Boston, Providence, even New York — and the abundant opportunities for entertainment, internships, and careers within our home city and beyond. Learn More about Worcester Find Your Clark Destination Campus Map Navigate your way around Clark University with our campus map. Getting from A to B, or even Z, is easy. Interactive Virtual Tour Campus Map Google Directions All roads eventually lead to Clark University. Find your most direct route here with Google’s help. Get Directions Visitor Parking Visitors driving to Clark will find several convenient areas to park while on campus. Parking permits are available from both the Undergraduate and Graduate Admissions offices. All cars parked in Clark University Parking Areas (see Printable Campus Map) must display this permit. Some on-street parking is permitted, but please check street signs carefully for restrictions. Undergraduate Admissions Office Please pick up a permit at: The Admissions Center 1 Maywood Street Admissions visitor parking is available in the Maywood Street Parking Lot. If this is full, please try the Downing Street Parking Garage next to the Kneller Athletic Center; enter and exit on Downing Street only. Spaces may also be available in the outdoor lot on Woodland Street (behind #2 on the Campus Map). Graduate Admissions Office Please pick up a permit at: The Graduate Admissions Office 122 Woodland Street Worcester, MA 01610 Parking is available in the outdoor lots on Woodland Street or Charlotte Street, or on the top level of the parking garage (#39 on the Campus Map), enter and exit on Downing Street only. Additionally, there is significant on-street parking in the area. Other Offices on Campus If you are not an Admissions Office visitor, please contact the office or academic department you are planning to visit to find out where you should park and obtain a permit. Traveling to Clark ... By Air You have two main options for traveling via air: Boston Logan International Airport , then take a train or bus from Boston to Union Station, Worcester, and a taxi/ride-hailing service from there to Clark. Worcester Regional Airport : JetBlue, American, and Delta fly to several U.S. destinations. Take a taxi/ride-hailing service from the airport to Clark, about four miles. Other airports include Providence, R.I. , Manchester, N.H. , and Hartford, Conn. , but getting to Clark from these locations is often more complicated than from the Boston or Worcester airports. Getting to Clark from Boston: The cheap but indirect route Take a train or bus to Union Station in downtown Worcester, where you will need to take a taxi or ride-hailing service to get to Clark. Getting to Clark from Boston: The direct but slightly more costly route Use a shared van/limousine service like Knights Limousine Service , to pick you up at Boston airport and bring you directly to campus. Many students use this option. Be sure to make reservations early and allow for travel time. The trip from Boston to Worcester can take more than an hour at peak travel times. This option is cheaper if you travel with a group. By Train Worcester’s Union Station is approximately three miles from campus. It’s serviced by Amtrak’s Lake Shore Limited and Regional Lines, and the MBTA Commuter Rail from Boston. The best way to get to Clark from Union Station is by taxi or ride-hailing service (information below). For train schedules and fares contact: Amtrak 1-800-872-7245 MBTA Commuter Rail 1-800-392-6100 By Bus Worcester’s Union Station is serviced by Greyhound and Peter Pan. The best way to get to Clark from Union Station is by taxi (information below). For bus schedules and fares from Boston, New York and Washington, D.C. contact: Greyhound 1-800-229-9424 Peter Pan 1-800-343-9999 By Taxi A taxi or ride-hailing service can bring you to Clark from Union Station (Worcester’s bus and train station): Bullet Yellow Cab: 1-508-754-3211 Red Cab: 1-508-792-9999 Uber Lyft Where to Stay in Worcester Recommended Hotels Below are nearby hotels recommended for families traveling to Clark for Undergraduate Admissions visits: AC Hotel Courtyard by Marriott Worcester Hampton Inn & Suites Worcester Holiday Inn Express Worcester Downtown Hilton Garden Inn Worcester For additional questions about traveling to Clark, please email admissions@clarku.edu . Worcester Transportation How can you travel to Clark University? Worcester’s transportation options have you covered by road, rail, and air. Direct flights via JetBlue, American Airlines, and Delta connect you to U.S. and international cities. Trains Worcester Regional Transit Authority (WRTA) Buses Worcester Airport Train Station People and Places Our Campus, Our Community Clark University, Worcester, MA Clark University grad student Stanley Greidinger builds a snowman on the campus green.
